Models (models)

The models module provides Arps decline curve fitting and prediction functionality.

decline_analysis.models.q_exp(t, qi, di)[source]

decline_analysis.models.fit_arps(t, q, kind='hyperbolic')[source]

Fit an Arps model to one decline series.

Parameters:

  • t (ndarray) – Time index (months from first production).

  • q (ndarray) – Production volumes.

  • kind (Literal['exponential', 'harmonic', 'hyperbolic']) – exponential, harmonic, or hyperbolic.

Return type:

ArpsParams

Returns:

ArpsParams with qi, di, and b (b=0 for exponential or 1 for harmonic).

decline_analysis.models.predict_arps(t, p)[source]

Predict with fitted Arps parameters.

Parameters:

  • t (ndarray) – Time points.

  • p (ArpsParams) – Arps parameters.

Return type:

ndarray

Returns:

Predicted rates.

decline_analysis.models.estimate_reserves(params, t_max=50.0)[source]

Estimate ultimate recoverable reserves using Arps decline curves.

Parameters:

  • params (ArpsParams) – Arps parameters (qi, di, b).

  • t_max (float) – Maximum time for integration (years).

Return type:

float

Returns:

Estimated reserves.

Mathematical Background

Arps Decline Curves

The Arps decline curves are fundamental models in petroleum engineering for forecasting production decline:

Exponential Decline (b = 0):

\[q(t) = q_i e^{-d_i t}\]

Harmonic Decline (b = 1):

\[q(t) = \frac{q_i}{1 + d_i t}\]

Hyperbolic Decline (0 < b < 1):

\[q(t) = \frac{q_i}{(1 + b d_i t)^{1/b}}\]

Where: - \(q(t)\) is the production rate at time t - \(q_i\) is the initial production rate - \(d_i\) is the initial decline rate - \(b\) is the hyperbolic exponent
